title: Demented post-war planners brutalised Britain with their concrete monstrosities. Demolish them
text:
Fine architecture, from cathedrals to the everyday beauty of a Victorian terrace, has the power to exalt the human spirit.

Bad architecture has the corresponding ability to depress it, and I speak as one who lives in a tower block with more than a passing resemblance to the miserable HQ of stationery supplier Wernham Hogg from The Office.

Encouragingly, the Government is giving people the chance to preserve the buildings that mean most to them, through a new local listing scheme. But it will take considerably more than that to reverse decades of urban blight. Why not go one step further and empower residents to recommend local eyesores for demolition?

The postwar decades removed much surviving...
